document.heading: Professional License Fee Amendment Act of 1994

history.narrative: Law 10-179, the “Professional License Fee Amendment Act of 1994,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 10-83, which was referred to the Committee of the Whole. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on June 21, 1994, and July 5, 1994, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on July 26, 1994, it was assigned Act No. 10-304 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 10-179 became effective on September 24, 1994.

LAW 10-179 "Professional License Fee Amendment Act of 1994 Pursuant to Section 412 of the District of Columbia Self-Government and Governmental Reorganization Act, P. L. 93-198 "the Act the Council of the District of Columbia adopted Bill No. I0-83 on first and second readings, June 21, 1994 and July 5, 1994, respectively. Following the signature of the Mayor on July 26, 1994, this legislation was assigned Act No. I0-304, and published in the August 5, 1994, edition of the D.C. Register (Vol.41 page 5210) and transmitted to Congress on August l, 1994 for a 30-day review, in accordance with Section 602(c)(I) of the Act, The Council of the District of Columbia hereby gives notice that the 30-day Congressional Review Period has expired, and therefore, cites this enactment as D,C, Law I0-179 effective Septembg~ 24, 1994, DAVID A. CLARKE Chairman of the Council Dates Counted During the 30-day Congressional Review Period: August 1,2,3,4,5,8,9,10,11,12,15,16,17,18,19,22,23,24,25,26 September 12,13,14,15,16,19,20,21,22,23 ENROLLED ORIGINAL AN ACT D,C, ACT 10-304 DiWlet of Co mbta Code L l| ’ ’ t~L 19,,95 IN THE COUNCIL OF TttE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA JULY 26, 1994 To amend the District of Columbia Income and Franchise Tax Act of 1947 to exempt certain attorneys engaged in pro bono and indigent legal services from the professional license requirements. BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act [nay be cited as the "Professional License Fee Amendment Act of 1994 Sec. 2. Section la(b) of title XIV of the District of Columbia Income and Franchise Tax Act of 1947, effective September 10, 1992 (D.C. Law 9-145; D.C. Code § 47-1814.1a(b is amended as follows a) Paragraph (1) is amended by striking the word "and" after the semicolon b) Paragraph (2) is mended to read as follows 2) An attorney who is an inactive member of the District of Columbia bar, a judge, or a retired judge eligible for temporary judicial assignment, who applies for and. is granted an exemption from the license required pursuant to section 1 of this title in accordance with the rules issued by the Mayor pursuant to section 1 of title XVI and who is not otherwise required to obtain a Heense pursuant to subsection (a) of this section; and c) A new paragraph (3) is added to read as follows 3) An attorney who is engaged in the provision of legal services, on a pro bono basis solely or in combination with government service in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection, or an attorney who is engaged in th.e provision of legal services solely as an employee or an affiliate of a nonprofit organization located in the District of Columbia that provides legal services for indigent clients without fee or for a nominal processing fee, who applies for and is granted an exemption from the license required pursuant to section 1 of this title in accordance with the rules issued by the Mayor pursuant to section. 1 of title XVI and. who is not otherwise required to obtain a license pursuant to subsection (a) of this section Section 47-1814. la See. 3. This act shall take effect after a 30-day period of Congressional review following approval, by the Mayor (or in the event of veto by the Mayor, action by the Council of the District of Columbia to override the veto) as provided in section 602(c)(1) of the District of Columbia Self-Government and Governmental Reorganization Act, Enrolled Original approved December 24, 1973 (87 Star. 813; D.C. Code § 1-233(c)(1 and publication in either the District of Columbia I~egister, the District of Columbia Statutes-at-Large, or the District of Columbia Municipal Regulations.
